Instructions: Select the dropdowns below to read about marketing.

  • What are we marketing to these audiences?
    • Recruiting children and families to enroll in the program
    • Recruiting possible employees for the program
  • The distinction between external marketing and internal marketing is:
    • External = focuses on recruitment efforts
    • Internal = focuses on retention efforts
  • Examples of the internal marketing audience include:
    • New families
    • Existing families
    • Past families
    • Staff
  • Why are we marketing to these audiences?
    • Ensuring families who are enrolled in the program, stay in the program.
  • Why do we need to focus on retention?
    • Families: More cost effective to retain a family until the children age out than it is to recruit a new family. Recruitment costs also include time that space remains unfilled (lost revenue), administrative time spent recruiting, enrolling and orienting a new family, and classroom time transitioning a new child.
    • Staff: More cost effective to retain qualified, productive staff than it is to recruit new staff. Recruitment costs for new staff include many of the same elements as recruiting a new family and can be even more expensive. Time spent on recruiting is time you cannot spend on improving the quality of your program, building relationships with children and families, and improving the workplace for staff.
